title: SoundHound Stock in Freefall. Here’s Why.

transcript.text:
You know how to tell someone's a Soundhound 
investor? They'll tell you. And it's SoundHound

AI. Don't forget the AI part. Today's video 
isn't just about SoundHound AI. It's chalkfull

of lessons on how to navigate the volatile 
world of AI stons. And make sure you watch

the entire thing because I'm also going to share 
some very difficult news I received this week. So,

the last time we looked at SoundHound AI, we said 
they were going to have a spectacular crash. So,

did they? Well, kind of. Depends on when you 
looked at the chart. So, I don't like this "aged

well" comments because, first of all, we can never 
really tell what the person's saying, whether they

mean that or they're being sarcastic. 90% of the 
time they're being sarcastic. But this chart shows

the price action for SoundHound AI since the last 
time we covered it, which was roughly a year ago.

So, if you watched that piece, I don't know, a 
couple weeks after it was published, you'd put,

"Well, this aged well because the price of the 
stock had gone up significantly." But then, if you

waited a while, indeed, there was a spectacular 
crash. So you could say this aged well. And then

of course it got pumped up again. So you could 
say this aged well. And then it went back down

and you could say this aged well again. So yes, 
it did age well. But what's more important to look

at is the price performance since this company had 
their SPAC debut. And you can see here that anyone

who bought shares of SoundHound AI when they had 
their SPAC would have underperformed the NASDAQ,

which isn't necessarily a bad thing because 
that means that while we didn't miss very much,

and if you invested now, then you'd presumably 
be investing at a reasonable valuation. However,

since most SPACs were overvalued, that doesn't 
necessarily add up. And we'll look at valuation

in a second. But when we go back and look at 
their SPAC deck, we can see these aggressive

targets they put down that never happened. That 
calls into question the company's ability to

execute. But let's put that aside and look at what 
growth they've been able to achieve thus far. Now,

this was taken from our last presentation. All 
we've done here is plotted their revenues out

over time, and then we extrapolated their guidance 
by quarter. So, we're going to go ahead and break

out these four quarters for 2025 and see what 
they actually did. And here we've done that. So,

red is the estimates that we had. Green is 
their actuals, and that black bar there,

that reflects this next quarter, what they're 
guiding towards. So, it seems like they're

tracking quite well to guidance. We'll talk about 
the revenue growth in a second. But what's on

exhibit here is really a typical SPAC playbook. 
You raise a bunch of money by making grandiose

promises. Then you realize that you'll never even 
come close to hitting those growth targets. So you

take your cash windfall and start buying companies 
to bolt on some growth. Now, one problem with that

is most acquisitions don't achieve synergies. And 
when you look at the hyped AI space right now,

what sort of bargains are you going to hope to get 
by purchasing AI companies right now? Probably not

very good ones, right?Yyou're probably going to 
pay a rich premium for whatever revenue you're

acquiring. And of course, you can point to this 
strong revenue growth they're experiencing as

some proof of greatness. But that just means 
that future growth is going to require more

acquisitions. And of course, they can issue shares 
until the end of time to fund more acquisitions

as long as they have the price support. And this 
appears to be exactly what they're doing. Rarely

does this strategy work out as planned. So, 
a number of consultancies have examined how

M&A works over time, and most M&A deals don't 
realize the synergies that are expected. And

here you can see the last time that we were able 
to plot out SoundHound's organic revenue growth,

which wasn't all that. And you can see they've 
made a number of notable acquisitions and continue

to make acquisitions. The question here is, will 
the synergies between these acquired companies and

the products they have in-house generate revenue 
synergies through cross-selling and such? Well,

that remains to be seen, but you need to ask 
the question of whether or not they're acquiring

quality. And when you look at the company's gross 
margins over time, you see here they've gone

from upwards of 70% down to 40%. That's rather 
misleading because if we consider amortization

their gross margins are somewhere around 60% which 
really isn't that bad. And you can go into the

earnings press release and look at the non-GAAP 
numbers, you see here amortization of intangibles

which relates to the acquisitions they made is 
distorting gross margin. So this is a fair use

of showing something in non-GAAP so investors can 
better understand that metric. Now when you look

at one of their competitors, Cerrence for example, 
they have much stronger gross margins, GAAP gross

margins, you see here around 80%. And what's more 
impressive, perhaps, is that they have positive

free cash flow. And that's something that when you 
look at SoundHound's investor deck and the sort

of language coming from the management team that 
I've seen, there's nothing relating to a sense of

urgency around getting to cash flow positive. 
And of course, when it comes to disruptive growth

companies, that isn't a priority necessarily, but 
there needs to be some visibility into that. And

we'd much rather opt for companies that have that 
in mind because whilst capital is very easy to

raise right now, that may not be the case around 
the corner. Now, when we look at their revenues,

I pulled up this table of revenues by geography 
and it's all rather interesting. So, Japan has

disappeared for some reason. And you can see here 
2025E represents an extrapolation of the first 9

months of 2025. So I don't understand what the 
expansion is in the other category. Korea seems

to be dropping off there. There's speculation 
that's actually Hyundai and that may have been

the customer concentration risk they had before. 
Then you see China emerging on the scene. That's a

bit of a concern because the Chinese are doing 
very well when it comes to voice recognition,

facial recognition, things like that. They've 
been doing a lot of work in that space,

and listening to Mandarin speakers is a lot 
different from listening to English speakers.

So that's something that certainly raised some 
eyebrows. So when you look at revenue growth,

they were officially guiding to 165 million in 
2025. That's a growth of 95%. Again, we don't

know how much of that is organic versus all the 
acquisitions they've been making. But now they're

guiding to 172.5 million. So growth of 104%. 
This question is key. What would revenue growth

be like without all these acquisitions? And that 
question is now very tough to answer as they've

merged their financials. If they stop acquiring 
companies, doesn't seem like they will. Then what

does their growth look like? More importantly, 
what sort of competition is there in this space

right now? Is this going to become a commodity 
offering? And I think everything leads us to

believe that it will. But before we get into that, 
there's something really difficult that I have to

tell you. I received some very unfortunate news 
yesterday. I never thought I'd have to say this,

but our Romanian fortune teller submitted 
her resignation letter via carrier pigeon,

of course, so it took a while to get here. So, 
to make up for her extended leave of absence,

she's offering all paying subscribers 12 basis 
points of Alpha each month until the end of the

year. So, a Nanalyze premium subscription not 
only pays for itself, and it already did before,

but now it actually makes you more wealthy, and 
better looking. Plus, we're actively searching

for her replacement. So, that means more alpha is 
coming down the road. When life hands us lemons,

we make lemonade. And speaking of lemons, 
let's get back to talking about SoundHound. So,

I like this piece here by Sierra Ventures. It's a 
market map of the over-150 AI voice companies out

there. And if SoundHound, being the pioneer that 
they are, had this all wrapped up, perhaps there

wouldn't be so much funding being poured into AI 
voice, and presumably, although that's probably

not a guarantee these days with all the hype, 
many of these, if not most of these AI startups

are showing strong growth. In other words, they're 
capturing market share that SoundHound AI isn't.

And perhaps the leader on that list would 
be Eleven Labs, and they recently had this

$100 million tender where they offer to buy shares 
back from existing investors and they're doing so

at a valuation of $6.6 billion. And in this press 
release, they talk about how earlier this year

they surpassed a $200 million annual run rate. 
Again, that's probably revenue that SoundHound

should have been grabbing, but perhaps it's just 
because these companies are targeting different

niches. And they're expected to grow that ARR to 
around 300 million by the end of this year. So,

let's take the most inflated valuation for 
Eleven Labs and the midpoint of that ARR number,

so $250 million, and let's calculate our simple 
valuation ratio, which is just market cap divided

by annualized revenues, we get 26. Well, now we 
have a valuation benchmark that we can use for

Soundhound. And when we plot SoundHound's simple 
valuation ratio over time, you can see that

number here. So the blue line represents the last 
four-quarter average. And we always tell investors

to have some sort of valuation metric that you can 
use and then set yourself a cut-off so you don't

get burned by hype. So 30 would be that cut-off 
if you took the last four-quarter average. Now,

for us, we don't invest in anything three times 
our catalog average, which sits, let's say,

somewhere around 7.5. So, let's say that's in the 
low 20s. So, I've marked that here with the red

line. And when you look at our catalog average, 
it becomes clear that SoundHound is objectively

overvalued. Now, you could argue that's because of 
all their growth, but again, when we go back and

look at what type of growth that is, it's growth 
by acquisition. And when you see this big spike

they have in valuation, that was probably around 
the time that everybody was raving about NVIDIA's

investment in SoundHound AI. And this was a slide 
taken from that last piece, we said NVIDIA's

investment is entirely meaningless, which is why 
it sits there doing nothing. That was based on the

size of their investment and how much equity it 
represented in the company, which probably since

then, has been significantly diluted. But that 
NVIDIA thesis evaporated when NVIDIA exited. So

this is their latest holdings. And just remember, 
what you see NVIDIA holding in their 13-F,

it doesn't mean what you think it does. And 
SoundHound is just another example of that.

Now speaking of dilution, it seems like dilution 
over at SoundHound is going to continue until

morale improves. And you can see here share count 
has more than doubled since their SPAC debut. So,

if you invested at $10 a share and share 
count doubles, then your shares are now worth

$5 a share, all things being equal. And one of the 
reasons share count is increasing so much is that

SoundHound has an at-the-market offering. So, they 
just sell shares into this hype, take the cash,

and then put it on their balance sheet and 
use that for acquisitions and for continuing

to burn through all the cash that the company is 
consuming. You can see here operating cash flows

over the past trailing 12 months about $100 
million. So they have an end cash position of

$268 million. You get about 2 and a half years 
left. That's pretty suitable. So when we look

at the conclusions of our last video, we said 
their very aggressive revenue targets should

be watched closely. Well, they're doing quite 
good there despite the fact that this is all

bolt-on revenue growth. And even if we look 
at their valuation using their 2025 target,

it's rather rich at an SVR of 27, though that's 
right around where Eleven Labs is, though Eleven

Labs seems to be a much more superior business in 
terms of quality. We said to watch gross margins

and especially operating margins for synergy. So, 
if they're going to realize all these benefits

from the companies that they're acquiring, then 
we want to see operating margins start to tighten

up. Obviously, they're ridiculously negative 
right now, but we want to see a trajectory

that's moving in the right direction there. One 
could argue that the acquired companies may be

masking a stagnation of organic revenues. Makes 
you wonder what all that R&D money that they're

spending is going towards. And it's going to be 
increasingly tough to decipher true growth with

this flurry of M&A activities. SoundHound AI 
isn't a buy for us. It's a bye. And we're not

short. We never short. It's bad idea. It's just 
that there are a lot better companies to look

at out there that aren't targeting a commodity 
offering that have much better valuations and

much better growth opportunities in front of 
them. Now, I know that a lot of folks out there

who treat investing like a pissing contest are 
going to be rather upset by some of the things

that we said today, but just remember that when 
someone casts a critical eye at your sacred cow,

that's really a good thing. And the pervasiveness 
of cheerleaders around this stock, that's really a

red flag. I don't know why it is that whenever you 
have a company that has an at-the-market offering,

there's always cheerleaders around. Odd. There's 
things to like, of course, about SoundHound,

mainly their revenue growth, which, while strong, 
is the result of M&A, and that's not what the SPAC

deck promised. Don't forget that. Now, this 
is going to age well in both directions. But

regardless, this isn't a company we would invest 
in. And if you want exposure to voice AI, ask

yourself why. This is a commodity offering that's 
likely going to be consumed by LLMs eventually.

If anything, Eleven Labs looks like a much more 
exciting way to play this. And whatever you do,

don't try to stockpick your way to wealth. That's 
actually a topic we covered in a recent video that

you ought to give a watch next. Thanks so much 
for taking the time to watch this video today.
